examples.text: Thick fog is <w>blanketing</w> the valley this morning.
They are <w>blanketing</w> the neighborhood with posters for the missing dog.

senses.sense_definition: A thick layer of something that covers a surface completely.

examples.text: A heavy <w>blanketing</w> of snow made the mountain roads impassable.
The cake was finished with a sweet <w>blanketing</w> of white frosting.

senses.sense_definition: Fabric or material used for making blankets.

examples.text: She purchased several yards of wool <w>blanketing</w> to sew covers for the winter.
The rough <w>blanketing</w> was warm but felt scratchy against the skin.

senses.sense_definition: A maneuver in sailing where one vessel blocks the wind from another vessel's sails.

examples.text: The captain used <w>blanketing</w> to slow down the rival boat during the race.
Effective <w>blanketing</w> can leave the other ship without enough wind to move.

senses.sense_definition: A layer of material placed under railway tracks to protect the ground below and improve drainage.

examples.text: Engineers installed sand <w>blanketing</w> to prevent the clay soil from shifting.
The track required new <w>blanketing</w> to remain stable under the weight of heavy trains.

senses.sense_definition: The act of tossing a person into the air using a blanket held by others, historically used as a punishment or hazing.

examples.text: The squire received a rough <w>blanketing</w> from the angry villagers.
Old stories describe <w>blanketing</w> as a form of public humiliation for minor offenses.
